ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My analysis and understanding of Baldwin greatly improved.
I learned so much about Baldwin's work, improved my critical writing skills, and I also learned the basics of making a podcast

I believe this class was maybe the most effective long-form conversation I've ever been a part of at Yale. It just flowed from one class to the next allowing thoughts to build through analysis of the text and listening to each other.
I learned how to think about literature in a interdisciplinary way
I learned so much about Baldwin, his works, and his connections to other intellectuals of the time.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved our discussions and think breakout room could have been better implemented.

I can't think of any weaknesses of this course! Prof. Goldsby is so knowledgeable, engaging, kind, and fantastic at leading/guiding discussion, our readings were obviously engaging, everyone in the class was interested in really discussing Baldwin's work, the assignments were fun and the workload was very manageable. Just a joy of a class.
Adapted to online learning very well -- lots of different ways of engaging with the class and the texts

Strengths: Professor Goldsby, discussion, reading list

Weaknesses: never ended on time!
Strengths are def Prof. Goldsby and Baldwin in conversation together!!!! The class will only improve when it's not over Zoom
The strength of the course: James Baldwin.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think over Zoom seminars can no longer just be discussions because our brains do not work like that. Thus, other interactive activities would have been beneficial.
I thought Professor Goldsby managed zoom incredibly well. I feel close to a whole community of people I only saw in virtual space
I thought all were very successful
The course succeeded as well as it could have.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend. Professor Goldsby is a star and a wonderful teacher. She takes the time to really understand what you care most about and her love of Baldwin makes the course even more engaging.

Absolutely; if you're interested in Baldwin's work, you should try to take this class. I'd only read a few of his essays before this course and I learned so much. It was such an engaging and rewarding seminar, even in the online format.
Yes. There isn't a better seminar at this school.
Yes, I loved the way the class was organized. Also Prof goldsby is a great facilitator of conversation and makes amazing points
Absolutely yes, to every single student

100% would I recommend this course! This is by far the best course I have ever taken during my time at Yale. A course that focuses entirely on the work of one writer is something that should happen more often at Yale. Being able to read Baldwin from the beginning of his career to the end really puts his work and framework into perspective in a way that would not be possible in another course. Baldwin's writing coupled with Professor Goldsby's guidance makes this the best course at Yale!
Absolutely!!!! Take it, no regrets
Yes. James Baldwin.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Discussion posts, online zoom seminars, virtual field trips,
N/A
